comment._content: I don't understand how a photo like this is possible without editing.  The sky is dark and defined yet the subject is illuminated, and yet not overly harsh as a flash might produce.  It looks like he was exposed for daylight, and the sky was a different photo.  Please, someone tell me how this is possible.

comment.author: 63822798@N00
comment._content: Presumably large format camera, 2-3 stop ambient underexposure with a flash fill, gelled with a warming filter and either umbrella or panel diffused, 45 degrees camera left, on a low depth of field.  Most 4x5 large formats only go to f/5.6 so this could be modified or the subject is far enough away from any other scenery to give the impression of a shallower scene.

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: taellinuaichi: The photographer for this image was Alfred T. Palmer. He worked for the Office of War Information News Bureau. Interestingly, in a 1990 interview, Palmer was actually somewhat critical of some of the Depression-era photographs produced by the Farm Security Administration (FSA). Speaking of Roy Stryker, who had headed the FSA unit for which Dorothea Lange worked and who later moved over to head an OWI photo unit, Palmer said, “He [Stryker] considered me a ‘glamour photographer’ who had to be taught the facts of life, but I felt that what he did at the FSA was manipulation—encouraging the photographers to show the worst conditions. I didn’t carry a skull on the back of my car to plant in the foreground of a picture to make a point. I didn’t light a sharecropper’s shack in such a way as to make it look as stark as possible. I believed in looking at the things in a helpful and encouraging manner.” (quoted in Nicholas Natanson, The Black Image in the New Deal: The Politics of FSA Photography (Knoxville: The University of Tennessee Press, 1992), 257-258. ) Palmer also did maritime photography - a listing for materials by him appears here: http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=tf4j49n761&doc.view=items&item.position=101&brand=oac. He apparently shot motion pictures, as well. There is a listing for a collection of his film work on this page: http://www.nps.gov/archive/safr/local/safrhdd.html.

comment.author: 12252057@N05
comment._content: A spectacular image, just goes to show the process of photography was essentally perfected by this time. The tools of the trade were a bit more tempermental but in the hand of the right professional they could yield an image as good or perhaps even better that we can today. My father shot alot of Kodak transparency film using his old Canon back in the 60's and the quality is beyond compare. Every time I look at them it amazes me, they could have been taken yesterday. In the digital age it easy to forget the chemical process and the beautiful images recorded for over  the last 150 years, I just dont think digital cameras are capable of this life like realism, at least not yet.
